awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Using RELAMPAGO Observations to Understand the Thermodynamic, Kinematic, and Dynamic Processes Leading to Heavy Precipitation
awd_abstract_narration:
RELAMPAGO (Remote sensing of Electrification, Lightning, And Mesoscale/microscale Processes with Adaptive Ground Observations) will observe convective storms in the lee of the Andes Mountains in central Argentina.  Storms in this region are poorly represented by weather and climate models and produce high impact weather in the lee of the Andes mountains in Argentina near the major cities of Cordoba and Mendoza. RELAMPAGO will be a 45-day project from 1 November - 15 December 2018.  RELAMPAGO examines what are perhaps the "world's most intense thunderstorms" per satellite observations, studying the processes that generate intense convection and severe weather that accompanies them, including heavy precipitation, severe hail and winds, and tornadoes.  By observing storms with new tools and techniques in detail in a region that has some similarities and key differences with the US Great Plains, RELAMPAGO is designed to make contributions to improve prediction of severe convective storms globally, including in the US. In addition, RELAMPAGO's international coordination is integrated to directly improve high impact weather prediction in Latin America. 

This project involves a collaboration between researchers at the University of Illinois and Colorado State University to study the processes that generate intense convection and precipitation in this region.  The project includes a network of research-quality fixed and mobile radars, atmospheric soundings, and storm process measurements in concert with other RELAMPAGO measurements (including from the DOE ARM Mobile Facility-1) to characterize the environment and internal structure of heavy-rain-producing storms. These measurements, value-added products, analyses, and modeling activities are focused on understanding the precursors and processes within and external to the storms to address hypotheses on relevant to heavy rainfall production in Argentinean convective storms in this poorly observed, yet vulnerable region. Research activities also include developing forecast models that are crucial for developing the field campaign operations and forecast planning. Contributions include RELAMPAGO education and outreach activities.

The region of the lee of the Andes mountains in west-central Argentina generates some of the most intense and organized convective systems on earth. These storms, initiated commonly near, and interacting with the complex terrain of the Andes and Sierras de Córdoba, produce frequent heavy rainfall that is known to lead to damaging flash floods. The RELAMPAGO (Remote sensing of Electrification, Lightning, And Mesoscale/microscale Processes with Adaptive Ground Observations) field campaign, from 1 November to 15 December 2018, is designed to provide a comprehensive array of profiling, surface, and remote sensing datasets with fixed and mobile platforms capable of characterizing the evolution of thermodynamic, kinematic, and microphysical measurements in and near convective storms on fine time and space scales. In this project, the NCAR S-PolKa dual-frequency dual-polarization, dual-wavelength S- and Ka-band radar, a network of Doppler on Wheels X-Band radars, frequent soundings, surface thermodynamic, kinematic, and microphysical measurements, and continuous water vapor profiling from the NCAR Water Vapor DIfferential Absorption Lidar (WVDIAL) platform, in concert with other RELAMPAGO measurements are used to characterize the environment and internal structure of heavy-rain-producing storms. These measurements, value-added products, analyses, and modeling activities focus on understanding the precursors and processes within and external to the convective storms to address hypotheses on relevant to heavy rainfall production in Argentinean convective storms in this poorly observed, yet vulnerable region. Leadership in research activities and configure forecast models that are crucial for developing the field campaign operations and forecast planning, as well as contributions to the RELAMPAGO education and outreach activities during the campaign are undertaken.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the principal investigator to oversee the RELAMPAGO (Remote sensing of Electrification, Lightning, And Mesoscale/microscale Processes with Adaptive Ground Observations, translates to lightning flash in Spanish and Portuguese) project, which was a collaborative project funded by the US National Science Foundation (NSF), National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), Servicio Meteorologico Nacional (SMN), Ministry of Education, Science and Technology of Argentina (MinCyT), Province of Cordoba, Brazil (INPE, CNPq, and FAPESP), and INVAP, S.E. to observe convective storms that produce high impact weather in the lee of the Andes mountains in Argentina. RELAMPAGO Extended Observing Period was 1 June 2018 ? 30 April 2019, while the Intensive Observing Period was 1 November ? 18 December 2018.  The PI also coordinated with the CACTI (Clouds, Aerosols, and Complex Terrain Interactions), which was a US Department of Energy (DOE) funded project to study orographic clouds and their representation in multi-scale models during 1 September 2018 ? 30 April 2019. It will involve the AMF-1 cloud-aerosol-radiation observatory, the Mobile Aerosol Observing System (MAOS), the CSAPR-2 precipitation radar, and a surface meteorological network. It also brout intensive airborne observations during RELAMPAGO through the deployment of the G-1 aircraft.

The principal investigator (PI) sucessfully completed the field phase of the project as proposed, and the PI oversaw that all data was delivered to relevant data centers according to the data agreement agreed upon by all PIs.  The PI also handled questions about the data and directed users to the relevant PIs, and data issues were fixed in the archive through updated datasets.  The PI successfully conducted an international data analysis workshop in Nov 2019. The PI worked with several PIs in analysis efforts following the campaign, which led to collaborative presentations and publications. 

It was discovered through RELAMPAGO observations that the terrain of the Sierras de Cordoba can enhance convective intensity through terrain-feedback processes that causes the thunderstorms that form near it to be locally more intense. The mesoscale flows in response to the heated mountain during the afternoon leads to a configuration of thermodynamic and wind shear conditions that leads to the rapid development of wide, rotating updrafts that produce strong cold pools.  Depending on the strength of the environmental flow, this configuration produces rapid upscale growth of convection, which due to the extreme nature of the convection, produces severe weather hazards (hail, wind, and hydrometeorological risk).  Controls on these effects were tested using observationally-inspired case studies and idealized cloud-resolving modeling experiments, verifying hypotheses about the role of the terrain, low level flow on convective initiation and upscale growth.

Through analysis of RELAMPAGO observations that mesoscale terrain can enhance conditions for convective intensity and the rate convective system growth beyond what can be expected by the storm environment "far" from the terrain, an effect that is not anticipated in global climate models.  It was also shown that mesoscale models can vary significant in the placement and intensity of precipitation in this regime.  RELAMPAGO observations used in advanced data assimilation approaches significantly improved the simulation of convective system evolution in this data sparse regime.  Efforts in forecast-informed reservoir operations in the Sierras de Cordoba were demonstrated and are one of the legacies of the RELAMPAGO project in improved water management in the region.  

This award has directly supported 3 PhD students at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign (2 have completed their degrees as of now).  It also supported 1 post doctoral scholar who went on to employment at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory.

It also has provided data for 2 undergraduate capstone research projects at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign.

Several talks, seminars, and conference presentations in the US and Argentina have dissemenated the results of RELAMPAGO, and these opportunities continue.

These include department seminars at the University of Illinois, University of Oklahoma, Penn State University, Colorado State University, San Jose State University, University of Buenos Aires, National University of Cordoba, Servicio Meteorologico Nacional (National Weather Service - Argentina), Province of Cordoba, Argentina, and National Center for Atmospheric Research.

Talks have been presented at American Meteorological Society (AMS) Annual Meetings, the AMS Mesosocale Conference and Mesoscale Symposium, the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting, workshops at the Department of Energy and National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

Informal talks have been presented at 2 local elementary schools in the Champaign-Urbana area, as well as for the Argentine weather outreach project MATTEO (matteo_ing.pdf (argentina.gob.ar) virtually and in person.

Major press coverage of RELAMPAGO was provided by the New York Times (What?s Going on Inside the Fearsome Thunderstorms of C?rdoba Province? - The New York Times (nytimes.com)), The Verge Magazine (Storm chasers are searching the clouds for the key to climate change (theverge.com)), and Nature (Argentina’s mega-storms attract army of meteorologists (nature.com))
